an6.20:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Nādika in the brick house.
an6.20:4.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
an6.20:4.3: “Mendicants, when mindfulness of death is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. It culminates in the deathless and ends with the deathless.
an6.20:4.4: And how is mindfulness of death developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial, to culminate in the deathless and end with the deathless?
an6.20:5.1: As day passes by and night draws close, a mendicant reflects:
an6.20:5.3: A snake might bite me, or a scorpion or centipede might sting me.
an6.20:5.4: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to me.
an6.20:5.5: Or I might stumble off a cliff, or get food poisoning, or suffer a disturbance of bile, phlegm, or piercing winds.
an6.20:5.6: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to me.’
an6.20:5.8: ‘Are there any bad, unwholesome qualities that I haven’t given up, which might be an obstacle to me if I die tonight?’
an6.20:6.1: Suppose that, upon review, a mendicant knows that
an6.20:6.2: there are such bad, unwholesome qualities. Then in order to give them up they should apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an6.20:6.3: Suppose your clothes or head was on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply intense enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an6.20:6.4: In the same way, in order to give up those bad, unwholesome qualities, that mendicant should apply outstanding enthusiasm …
an6.20:7.1: But suppose that, upon review, a mendicant knows that
an6.20:7.2: there are no such bad, unwholesome qualities. Then that mendicant should meditate with rapture and joy, continuing to train day and night in wholesome qualities.
an6.20:8.1: Or else, as night passes by and day draws close, a mendicant reflects:
an6.20:8.3: A snake might bite me, or a scorpion or centipede might sting me.
an6.20:8.4: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to me.
an6.20:8.5: Or I might stumble off a cliff, or get food poisoning, or suffer a disturbance of bile, phlegm, or piercing winds.
an6.20:8.6: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to me.’
an6.20:8.8: ‘Are there any bad, unwholesome qualities that I haven’t given up, which might be an obstacle to me if I die today?’
an6.20:9.1: Suppose that, upon review, a mendicant knows that
an6.20:9.2: there are such bad, unwholesome qualities. Then in order to give them up they should apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an6.20:9.3: Suppose your clothes or head was on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply intense enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an6.20:9.4: In the same way, in order to give up those bad, unwholesome qualities, that mendicant should apply outstanding enthusiasm …
an6.20:10.1: But suppose that, upon review, a mendicant knows that
an6.20:10.2: there are no such bad, unwholesome qualities. Then that mendicant should meditate with rapture and joy, continuing to train day and night in wholesome qualities.
an6.20:11.1: Mindfulness of death, when developed and cultivated in this way, is very fruitful and beneficial. It culminates in the deathless and ends with the deathless.”
